top_comment.text: Where's Brazil on this list? Gov't Corruption - 100%﻿
top_comment.author: Andreneida Letícia

comments.text:
+Andreneida Letícia Yeah...that's why I had a big problem with moving 
there.I have a business but found that you needed 120,000 to get 
incorporated  there and it takes 120 days to get incorporated. Plus the 
import tax that they charge for imported goods.I wasn't aware how backwards 
Brazil was.And it's supposed to be the economic leader in South & Latin 
America.
I'm not saying Brazil is a awful country but the corruption is absolutely 
horrendous as is the poverty and income disparity. And the citizens feel so 
powerless to stop it. But I will give Brazil this...they have the most 
considerate, caring, loving, and feminine women on the planet. I'm pretty 
sure I won't find a wife here in the States but will sure as hell try to 
find one there...lol.
comments.author: INIR2

comments.text:
The health system here is not so good either (at least it's free - which 
doesn't make it any better). The taxes are ridiculously high! When the PS4 
came out the price here was so high, that I could take a plane, go the USA 
buy it there, comeback and still spend less than if I would if I bought it 
here. The problem is, that in the airport they would probably charge me 
more taxes for bringing it in... smh
comments.author: Andreneida Letícia

comments.text:

think of living there.

I'm from Romania, and  indeed, we don't approve of our Goverment, but 
mostly we don't approve of our president. The elections for presidency are 
coming next month, but most of the candidates that are backed up by a party 
aren't suited to be president, which is quite a sad situation really. None 
of the prominent candidates are saying something about protecting  Roșia 
Montana, which is a very important issue about protecting our enviroment (4 
mountains to be exact) from being blown up by foreign companies (the 
Canadian company Gold Corporation) in order to extract gold, which only 10% 
will be given to the Romanian treasury. It's a really complicated 
situation, but the main reason is the corruption and greed of the 
politicians >.<﻿

comments.text:
+dubtat One poll the perception was incorrect .. Another it was correct .. 
each separate perception has to be be evaluated on its own merit.  You can 
not lump them all together like you are attempting to.
comments.author: sharper68

comments.text:
+sharper68 Fail again. You keep trying to change the subject. The poll 
showed that facts and perception aren't related. The study was about 
perception. Stop putting a spin on it to justify your bias.
comments.author: dubtat

comments.text:
+dubtat You keep missing the point that saying factual things matters.  Fox 
viewers are more poorly informed than people who watch no TV.  This is 
because what they share is often not attached to reality.  Comparing what 
fox does to what TYT does is total fail.  Fox and Rush lie and that is 
their problem not that they change perceptions.
comments.author: sharper68

comments.text: +sharper68 It's good to know you're pro-FoxNews. Good luck with that.
comments.author: dubtat

comments.text:
+dubtat The assertion that any effort spent on changing opinion is innately 
bad or undesirable is false.  The only downside to  these programs that 
change peoples perception is when they misrepresent the truth.  Information 
in general changes peoples perception and what they say matters.  They part 
ways with Rush because what they say is factually correct.  It is incumbent 
on you as someone who says otherwise to back up your spin.
comments.author: sharper68

comments.text:
+sharper68 If TYT's goal isn't to change peoples perception, then what is 
it? Based on how little time they dedicate to stating the facts and how 
much time they spend putting their spin on said facts, their goal certainly 
is not to report news. Your problem is that you drank their Kool-Aid and 
now you can't see the forest for the trees.
comments.author: dubtat

comments.text:
+dubtat It does not make them "part of the problem" to comment on these 
issues.  The only way you make them the same is as Rush is if you ignore 
the value of their commentary or damage that is done because of it.  That 
they both do commentary does not mean they are the same.
comments.author: sharper68

top_comment.author: Maka Crimon

comments.text:
Technically, we live in a democracy and could fix the problems without too 
much fuss. However, we have been conditioned from birth to think shooting 
people is the only way to make the bad guys comply. We have also been 
brainwashed to think massive corruption is the norm because governments are 
inherently evil. Furthermore, the people with the guns tend to be the same 
sort of idiots who push for the policies that allow corruption while 
complaining about corruption and being belligerent towards those trying to 
reduce corruption.

So, I think there is this feeling that the only way to get rid of the 
corrupt politicians is a bloody revolution because guns are the solution to 
everything. Even if that works, we'll just get another corrupt government 
because governments are always evil. And the potential revolutionaries are 
mostly knuckle dragging idiots who will screw things up worse than they are 
now with either an even more corrupt government, or the bunch of little 
thiefdoms dictatorships that would arise if we tried anarchy.

In short, the perception is that things can only get worse. It is a sort of 
societal depression created by mass media colluding with government and big 
business to induce hopelessness to prevent us from even trying to fix 
things. Even shorter, we are crazy. Until we get better, we won't do 
anything about it, at least nothing productive and that makes the 
troublemakers happy and secure.

be socialist. Second of all, the US economy isn't terrible, but it isn't

multinational corporations. I should image in countries like Scandinavia 
who have weeded out third world corruptions, maintains a fairer economic 
system and doesn't have so many nut jobs cuckoo for cocoa pops I should 
think government favourability is a lot higher.
comments.author: Easternodyssey

comments.text: Autocracies of course
comments.author: maxracer176

captions.text: Gallup has done a study called "Global States of Mind 2014". They released it with the Meridian Global Leadership Summit and it tracks how disaffected people are with their government all throughout the world.

Well, that's very interesting, I wanna see who came in at the bottom here, they have the bottom twelve. They're actually slightly wrong, there's one other country that we need to show you about, I'll get to that in a minute.
But first, what are the factors for why people might be dissatisfied with their government? Well, three factors are listed as the main ones and I think they make sense:
If your economic future looks bleak, well then you of course don't have a great perception of your government.

That's very important, 'cause a lot of countries have a lot of education, but also high unemployment, so it seems like they should have a lot of potential, but the reality is not so good and that creates a really big problem.
And then the third one I believe is the most important:
And you'll see in the numbers how well that matches up, OK?
First, let me show you one piece of number that they quoted here in 24/7 Wall St. that explained this phenomenon:
So out of the bottom twelve, 10 of them thought the corruption was totally out of control.
So, let's go quickly through the list from twelve to number one, OK?
And then I'll add the last country.

If you only saw this country, you'd say "Well, look, that unemployment rate is unbelievable. That probably has a lot more to do with it than any other factor." But keep going. Now you go to Portugal next.
Now that's ten percent lower than Spain, but still disastrous, right? Now, let's go to Jamaica.

So, those three are in agreement: bad unemployment, bad corruption leads to great dissatisfaction with the government. Alright, now here is where it starts to get a little interesting. Costa Rica is next.
Now, that's not great, but it's not disastrous. There's a lot worse in the world. So, for Costa Rica apparently the number one issue doesn't appear to be unemployment.

But corruption is always the standard. Number one concern, OK? Again, that's me looking at the numbers here and interpreting it in ways that other people have interpreted as well, you look at the numbers, make your own decision. Romania:
But still they're in the top twelve most dissatisfied with their government. Same in Peru:
- this is really interesting -
I wouldn't have guessed that.

So, that is not a bad rate at all given the world context. So, Pakistan - the unemployment rate is not the biggest issue, clearly. But like most of these other countries, four out of five people saying "This government sucks, it's so corrupt.", OK? Moldova is next.
Well, God bless the economy of Moldova. It's a little bit more complicated than that, but you know what? Obviously, the unemployment is not the issue there.
Czech Republic:
Greece - unemployment rate again becomes a huge problem:
- one of the largest numbers in the world -

OK. So what's the one country they left out? Well, in all of these countries they ask "Do you approve of your government?". When they came to the US, the metric that they used was President Obama's approval rate, which is at forty-two percent. Now, that's not good, but it's much better than these numbers, right?

But wait a minute, that's not whether we approve of our government or not. That number is very partisan. So, a lot of Republicans will hate President Obama, just because he's from the other party, but a lot of Democrats will support President Obama, just 'cause he's from their party.
If you ask about our government, congress - not Republican or Democrat, not an individual candidate, but congress - in 2013 we were at
Now, to be fair to us, we have improved vastly. This year we're at
So, in fact, if you put the US with the proper reading of the numbers into this system, we hate our government second most in the world. Thank God for the Bosnians.
If it wasn't for the Bosnians, we'd be number one in approval of our government. We hate our government. Now, here's what's interesting:

unemployment rate's not bad, 5.9%. "Believe government corruption is widespread." Now, if you ask a question in that way, you're not gonna get 96%. But if you ask the question "Do you believe that money has a corrupting influence on our politics, our government?", there is a poll on that. It's 96%.

So, even though our unemployment isn't bad economically, we're actually doing fairly well compared to the rest of the world, Europe is struggling a lot more than we are and obviously other parts of developing world are struggling more - some are doing better, right? But overall, our economic context is not bad.
But we believe, that money has corrupted our politics entirely. 96% of the country believes that.
So hence, our dissatisfaction with our government is sky-high. Second worst in the world.

That's the reality of the American government. If you don't get money out of politics, people will continue to be dissatisfied, because they understand - whether it's conscious or unconscious - they know in their bones that these so-called representatives don't represent us.
They represent the people who pay them, their donors. We already have that memo. The next memo is how we fix it.
You wanna see where that memo is? You go to wolf-pac.com. We have the plan to fix it, we've already begun the plan, we've already had success in that plan.
And we're not gonna stop until we clean it up.

Now here is the day I look forward to. Not only do we get the 28th amendment, getting money out of politics, but when they do a poll - many years later - and all of a sudden - after we've solved the corruption problem the best we can, my guess is that the approval rating of congress is nowhere near 12%,

that it is significantly, shockingly higher. You think "Oh no, that's not true. We've always hated our congress." Not true. Before money poured into the system with a couple of supreme court decisions in the 1970s that changed everything, allowed corporations to give unlimited money to politicians,

that's where it began. Not at Citizens United, it started in 1976 and 1978. Before that, congressional approval ratings were actually rock-solid. They weren't in the 90s or the 80s or anything, but compared to the rest of the world, they were wonderful.
Because congress at that time, before the money came in, actually represented us. And it can again. We are supposed to perfect this union.
That's what the founding fathers intended. Let's do it. Let's get the amendment passed and rewrite the code, make sure that we fix this virus in the system.
The way to do it is at wolf-pac.com.

title: Most Hated Government By Its Own People? The Winner Is...
